reviewText: To people not familiar with Prototype 1, I recommend it, it's a power fantasy and a lot of fun. There are references to the first game but it's not needed to have a fun time. This game is a Power Fantasy and it does that in spades, you feel powerful. Enjoy. My review below is for people who have played and enjoyed the plot and storyline of the original Prototype.\n\nTo fans of the original Prototype, this game is about the same. It's a big more organized, with a bit more work put into it. But it has the same progression and feels very much like you are just playing the original Prototype with a few extras added in. If you feel a Prototype itch" this may be a decent game to pick up if it was heavily discounted
date: but I generally do not recommend this game. I do not recommend it because the completion of this game left a bad taste in my mouth. I enjoyed the original Protoype
recommended: and loved the story and the plot. But this game throws it all away. Because (Spoilers)  Alex Mercer

reviewText:
I love the Prototype series and having played both of them the second one is definitely the best option on console... ON CONSOLE. Prototype 2 is definitely not worth your money for the PC version, it's a shoddy port that I had problems getting to run (the game has a problem with some HID Hardware meaning that I had to unplug my keyboard in order for the game to run.) and then when it did finally work I was hovering between 30 and 40 FPS and the graphics don't warrant the game dropping below 100 let alone 40 FPS.

I can't comment on the port of the original Prototype as I have only played the second one on PC.

If you have an Xbox 360 or PS3 I would definitely recommend that you buy it for one of those machines; it provides hours of fun and an unprecedented sense of power. However avoid at all costs if you are planning to buy it on PC.

reviewText:
Let's clarify. I WOULD absolutely recommend this game if it was not so definitely broken.

No matter if you have a last gen pc with tons of ram (i have 32GB) and a last gen video card (i use AMD wit 2GB). The game lags and crashes every about 10 minutes. It's just a bad porting.

Too bad because there are some aspects in which the game really shines. Graphics are very cool, when the frame rate doesn't drop. Controls are improved, and the overall impression, compared to the first episode, is of that a world which is actually alive (also thanks to the motion capture movements and the improved usability).

There are also some ponts where, I think, the game is actually worse than the first chapter, like the start of the game (I liked the immediately in the game

Many complaining that this is a bad port etc...
Compared to many other ports this one is frekkin awsome, imho one of the better ones.
Max settings, no lag, nice controls, no problem. Guessing It's ♥♥♥♥♥♥ computers or/and crap behind the keyboard at play here.

As for the game I prefere Prototype 1, can't say why, i just do, it had another feel to it.
With that said this is still a really nice game with many fun elements in it.
And i do recommend it to ppl that liked Prototype 1 or hack n slash in general.

Is it worth 30€? Few games are as i see it, but a 3 year old game? no and no,,shame on you.!
Pick it up on a sale, unless you reheeally want to play it now.

reviewText:
First of all let me start off this review by stating the the game shipped broken and was never fixed.  It always had a bad memory leak and certain missions would cause it to crash.  But now since the Omega Drivers release from AMD and the subsequent upgrade to Windows 10 it is time to remove this game from Steam.

The game is completely broken.  Under Win 8.1 and the AMD 14.2 drivers you could mostly play until the memory leak ended your fun.  If you decide to run an older OS and even older drivers, you can have fun in the game.  Really it's not a bad game and at times is quite fun!  On a scale of 1 - 100 I would give it a solid 65 with the memory leak lowering the score to 57.

Under Windows 10 the game will actually start, but then the memory leak ends the fun after 5 minutes.  Everyone is going to upgrade to Windows 10 for DX12 games.  Thus this game is completely dead.

Please Valve remove this game from the Steam Store.  There is no reason to leave abandoned games on your storefront.    I wish Activision had allowed the original development team to patch the game, but alas that's the current state of PC development I suppose.  Release, promote, and run.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

All I know is that on my hd 6970 it wont work.\n\nThe fact that a game can be relesed in this state is totally unacetable. Low frame rates, constant crashing and even the menus don't work properly. I tried all the fixes that people where suggesting online and none of them worked. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME IF YOU HAVE AN ATI CARD

reviewText:
A lot of people complain about the sequel's various glitches. I have not encountered any and have been able to fully enjoy the gaming experience without any issues.



Prototype 2 is a direct follow-up to its predecessor and although in terms of story telling it does not really offer anything new it is still engaging and its combat it's still super fast and fun.



Graphics has been enchanced to a level where you can only call this game gorgeous (its red zone is certainly a beauty) and while your first playthrough will take less time to complete it certainly is a recommended game.

reviewText:
I loved Prototype 2 and completed it, even though I struggled to play through the first game.

The graphics are decent, the controls are great (with a pad) and I didn't get any technical issues, however the forums are full of people with stuttering caused by memory leaks.

I played on SLI 670's with an i5 2500k and had no issues.

The combat here is fantastic, brutal and gory.  The addition of vehicle takedowns makes you feel like a complete badass, and the new ability to turn people into infested grenades is brilliant.

Would recommend to anyone with the caveat that you might have some technical issues.

reviewText:
I had bought this game, as I enjoyed the original Prototype a lot.

Unfortunately the game is nothing like it's older brother. You play as one of the characters you have briefly met in the original Prototype, and apparently after the whole first story, a epidemic found place. Alex Mercer (main character of the original Prototype) the one behind this epidemic, and so the bad guy of Prototype 2.

In the original Prototype, the ending showed nothing of Alex turning bad, maybe even the opposite.

The game developers turn this new guy into the hero, but you never really feel any form of 'connection' with him. He just seem to be angry and blindly run, and act by rage all the time. I never have a lot with characters that act this way.

Aside from that the main story is rather short, and switches from one side, to the other... it almost feels like the developers re-thought the storyline halfway through the process... deciding to change the whole story hafway through.

The game never really feels to run truely smooth and the gameplay overal just isn't really working... As a keyboard/mouse player, I sometimes felt like I was making a sailorsknot in my own fingers. You ofcourse can change the buttons & actions linked to them, but it still never really works for me. Therefor I never did many side missions, as the whole buttonpart irritated me quite a bit.

The experience might be a lot better with a controller to your PC.

It does have a lot of nice, and gory situations, the developers sure have took their time on making things look really disgusting. ;) & Ofcourse the transformations of your character are just like Alex's really nice. The whole sword/arm, and rest of the transformation arsenal are still amazing to use and lovely to see.

Overall most of the game just didn't feel right. It had the feel of not being properly finished, and being rushed for the deadline. (Which I am aware of; is now years ago.)

reviewText: Bought this game a while ago when it was on sale and just recently got around to playing it. I know a lot of people are saying they can't play it due to technical issues, but I haven't experienced any issue when playing the game. 3 1/2 years since its release and the grphics are still decent even compared to some of the games released nowadays. The controls are easy and flows very nicely. The gameplay is somewhat easy, nothing can really stop you once you get the hang of the abilities, but the game is very fun. The story is there, but the missions are somewhat repetitive, and the upgrades don't seem very meaningful aside from the evolutions. Game is currently on sale again so now is the time to buy it if you like open world, kill everything games with a bit of stealth. Wouldn't recommend at the original £20 price tag but definitely worth £5.

reviewText:
This is a first impression review, and as such you should only consider this from the view point of someone who hasn't seen much of this game. But what I have seen is downright atrocious. This is one of the worst PC ports I've played, and right now it isn't worth a penny until it gets fixed.
I regret paying even spending £5 on it, it's has the most unstable frame rate drops I've encountered, struggling to hit 30, then plummeting down to 5 fps without explanation. But it's ok, it's not unpredictably buggy, because it happens constantly, regardless of what I'm doing.
It's so bad that the game becomes almost impossible to control, and I wasn't able to play any more than a few minuets before getting a headache. Because of the poor K&M controls it's best to play this with a game pad, then, and only then is this game remotely manageable.
But from a design point of view it seems to fall for the usual mistakes that a lot of major release games do, the opening of the game gives you no control, holding you hand all the way through a series of frustrating QTE's, that you can't even fail because time stops, so you can sit under the fist of a giant monster for 5 minutes while it waits for you to click, this is Rambo: The Video Game level of design (but don't worry, you still get an achievement at the end of that level... >.> )

I heartily recommend that you don't buy this game for any money, unless you want to spend you valuable time fiddling with community made patches trying to get this broken mess working, because this game has not been patched by the developers or Activision after 2 years.

reviewText: I dug both titles for a little while. It was fun running around this big city with super powers, running up buildings, gliding around, destroying tanks and cars, doing some mini challenges here and there, but after a while it all wears off when you realize that there really isn't a lot more to this game than that. The mechanics seemed good enough at first, but later on the controls and mechanics just get in the way and cause bouts of frustration when battling bosses and harder enemies, using either keyboard and mouse or controller. Luckily I got both the 1st and 2nd Prototype games in a bundle deal that was about the same price as a couple of sandwiches. I wouldn't ever pay more than that for them. Fun for a little while, but dissapointing in the long term. Can't really recommend either of them.

reviewText:
The visual engines of both Prototype games behave in a strange manner:

1. They need to run at 60 frames per second on 60 Hertz to have smooth motion, were it not for the insane amounts of stuttering. This stuttering looks very much like an extremely severe case of microstutter, yet I only run a single GPU setup (1 x GTX 780 TI).

2. Running the games beyond 60 fps (either through disabling the vsync or running at higher Hz) make them look like a 30 fps game. It looks like the engine repeats every frame even though any framerate counter will state that the games run smoothly at any Hz rate the monitor is set. (eg. 100 fps on a 100 Hz display, but it looks exactly like running a constant 50 fps on 100 Hz.)

Both engine faults give me a headache when I try to play the games.

I've tried every fix" I could find on the internet (including disabling all HID devices
date: running at the lowest in-game graphics settings
voteText: using the resolution fix .dll
helpfulPercent: etc.) and none worked for me.\n\nSo I know this isn't much of a review of the game itself. It might be good
votesHelpful: but I never got to experience it myself because of these technical issues which I admit being sensitive to. Therefore
votesTotal: I can hardly recommend the game

reviewText:
I wouldn't recommend buying this game, unless it's on a 75% reduction in price. The issues with this game are unreal: lag is bad, it's poorly optimised, and the bugs in this game are so awful! The game has recently started crashing on loadup, not a CTD, it freezes on  the title screen before I can even press a key/button now.

However, the game is beautiful, the storyline is brillaint and James Heller is a badass with a somehwat dark sense of humour that has had me giggling to myself every now and then. The gameplay is smooth, and the powers and abilities you gain grow and evolve in order to make you nearly invincible, and this limitless power is what makes this game, and its predeccesor have so much fun.

I would definitely recomend getting this game though, if it were on sale and/or have a console, and if you played Prototype 1, then I would say buying this is definitely worth it.

8.5/10 for non-PC --> great graphics and immersive gameplay and storyline
3/10 for PC --> poorly optimised PC port

reviewText:
So, I have some complaints about this game.

1. The game freezes on start up and has to have its process ended in the task manager, more often than not.

2. If you manage to get past the start up freezes, the game will crash every 10-15 mins.

3. The opening cinematic gave me a massive headache.  I was worried that I was gonna have a seizure with how much flashing happens.

4.  Doesnt really seem to be anything new gameplay wise.

If you didnt have any of these problems, I guess you are lucky.  Maybe get this one for console if you dont want to face the endless crashes.  Buy at own risk!

reviewText:
Can't recommend this, unfortunately. After installing, I first had to spend about 1,5 hours trying to get the game to run beyond the intro (which was, admittedly, awesome). I finally managed to solve the problem with help from others in the forums and eagerly sat down to play.

I uninstalled the game after 45 minutes of play time.

I loved the original Prototype because of the way that its story was told and because the factions involved (Blackwatch specifically) were interesting. Not dog-kickingly evil, but clearly not nice, either - just trying to prevent the spread. The gameplay was lots of fun too, but that wasn't what led me to get Prototype 2. If you are all about the gameplay, this review might not apply to you.

In the short span of time I played, I was dismayed to find that the interesting-seeming protagonist was, in fact, a violent and stupid thug with no redeeming qualities, easily led and manipulated. The game's villain was apparent right from the start and was all but moustache-twirlingly evil. Blackwatch appears to have become an organization of deathly stupid dog-kicking nazis who (minor spoiler) release infected into test areas" apparently just for the fun of it.

The open-world gameplay didn't work for me either; I found the city area cluttered and overly full. The new look works and it makes sense to have people sleeping rough etc.
date: but I missed the clear lines of the first game. The control change for gliding and airdash REALLY annoyed me as well
recommended: especially as I had replayed the entire first game and scored platinum on all movement events for the fun of it just before starting the second. I loved the way movement flowed in the first game and it just seemed completely unnecessary to change it in the second.\n\nSome of the mechanics seemed promising (consuming specific evolved to gain certain powers
voteText: but all in all
helpfulPercent: the cartoonish "villains" and idiot unsympathetic protagonist killed this game for me very quickly. What a shame."

reviewText:
This is a first impression review, and as such you should only consider this from the view point of someone who hasn't seen much of this game. But what I have seen is downright atrocious. This is one of the worst PC ports I've played, and right now it isn't worth a penny until it gets fixed.
I regret paying even spending £5 on it, it's has the most unstable frame rate drops I've encountered, struggling to hit 30, then plummeting down to 5 fps without explanation. But it's ok, it's not unpredictably buggy, because it happens constantly, regardless of what I'm doing.
It's so bad that the game becomes almost impossible to control, and I wasn't able to play any more than a few minuets before getting a headache. Because of the poor K&M controls it's best to play this with a game pad, then, and only then is this game remotely manageable.
But from a design point of view it seems to fall for the usual mistakes that a lot of major release games do, the opening of the game gives you no control, holding you hand all the way through a series of frustrating QTE's, that you can't even fail because time stops, so you can sit under the fist of a giant monster for 5 minutes while it waits for you to click, this is Rambo: The Video Game level of design (but don't worry, you still get an achievement at the end of that level... >.> )

I heartily recommend that you don't buy this game for any money, unless you want to spend you valuable time fiddling with community made patches trying to get this broken mess working, because this game has not been patched by the developers or Activision after 2 years.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I dug both titles for a little while. It was fun running around this big city with super powers, running up buildings, gliding around, destroying tanks and cars, doing some mini challenges here and there, but after a while it all wears off when you realize that there really isn't a lot more to this game than that. The mechanics seemed good enough at first, but later on the controls and mechanics just get in the way and cause bouts of frustration when battling bosses and harder enemies, using either keyboard and mouse or controller. Luckily I got both the 1st and 2nd Prototype games in a bundle deal that was about the same price as a couple of sandwiches. I wouldn't ever pay more than that for them. Fun for a little while, but dissapointing in the long term. Can't really recommend either of them.

reviewText:
Protoype 2 has absolutely awful optimisation issues when run on AMD cards. Animations won't play, FPS drops on a card that has no business going below 60, and random game crashes which make the game near impossible to play for more than half an hour at a time.

It's disappointing, because the game itself is a lot of fun. The writing is pretty terrible, but the core game is markedly improved from the first Protoype.

It's still worth playing, but do your research before hand to see how badly the game will run on your machine/

reviewText:
Bought this and Prototype in a steam sale a while back, just got around to playing it... and it is absolutely *plagued* with technical issues.  The framerate chugs, the audio lags behind the video in cutscenes, and the inputs are severly delayed out of box.

At first, the game wasn't even playable.  After rolling my drivers back to a version that's severly out of date, I managed to gain enough control to get past the menu screen.  It was fine for a while, but having several enemies on screen still caused the framerate to chug - even with everything set to low" or "off".

My machine has run much more recent/intense games without missing a beat
date:
so I have trouble believing the issue is on my end:

================================================
AMD FX 8320 3.5 Ghz 4 Physical/ 8 Virtual Cores
32GB RAM
AMD Radeon 6950 (2GB DDR5
hoursPlayed:
DirectX11
================================================

Don't buy this game - save your money and your sanity."

reviewText:
Basically the same game: With only a couple more weapons added and a different protagonist who has the exact same powers and skills as the 1st just now with a different skin and voice. Mechanics and missions were not that different. Short campaign, repetitive missions, lackluster character investment, poor port.

Essentially this sequel lacked any creativity. They did improve finding collectibles, and they injected some humorous dialogue, but for me it really wasn't enough to elevate this game.

You're probably better off getting the 1st Prototype for less you'll get a better story and bosses. It's a fun game if you just want to mindlessly kill and blow up stuff, but then there's prototype 1 for this.

reviewText:
The visual engines of both Prototype games behave in a strange manner:

1. They need to run at 60 frames per second on 60 Hertz to have smooth motion, were it not for the insane amounts of stuttering. This stuttering looks very much like an extremely severe case of microstutter, yet I only run a single GPU setup (1 x GTX 780 TI).

2. Running the games beyond 60 fps (either through disabling the vsync or running at higher Hz) make them look like a 30 fps game. It looks like the engine repeats every frame even though any framerate counter will state that the games run smoothly at any Hz rate the monitor is set. (eg. 100 fps on a 100 Hz display, but it looks exactly like running a constant 50 fps on 100 Hz.)

Both engine faults give me a headache when I try to play the games.

I've tried every fix" I could find on the internet (including disabling all HID devices
date: running at the lowest in-game graphics settings
voteText: using the resolution fix .dll
helpfulPercent: etc.) and none worked for me.\n\nSo I know this isn't much of a review of the game itself. It might be good
votesHelpful: but I never got to experience it myself because of these technical issues which I admit being sensitive to. Therefore
votesTotal: I can hardly recommend the game
votesFunny: now can I? I did
commentsCount: after all
column16: not have a fun time playing this game.\n\nAs such I feel I need to not recommend it. You might not have issues with it however
column17: so keep that in mind. Yet
column18: I still wanted to write these words of warning to those few people who might have issues with this game if smooth motion is kind of a must for them
column19: or to those who loathe bad PC ports in general."

reviewText:
Honestly the best game I've ever played. I wish there were more games where I could play god in a sandbox. I've played many many games, as shown by my profile, and this is by far the best. Extremely fluent combat, satisfyingly brutal.

It's better than the first because of the direction of the jumping. In the first game, you would jump vertically, and then would glide to near buildings. In this game, you jump at a 35 degrees angle in front of you. You still jump really high, but you also jump reaaaally far, which makes the whole parkour a blaze.

EDIT: Played some 300h on ps3.

reviewText: Prototype 2 is one of my favourite open world games of all time, with a bigger focus on combat and better controls than the first game, this PC version both looks and runs better than the original console versions ever did. Stealth is always an option rather than outright charging into combat, and is sometimes necessary on harder difficulties to get out of a mess, but it's clear the focus of the developers was on causing as much chaos with your nigh-invulnerability as possible. The only con is the story and main character somehow manage to be worse than the first game, but that's never been important to either title in the series in the first place.

reviewText:
I loved Prototype 2 and completed it, even though I struggled to play through the first game.

The graphics are decent, the controls are great (with a pad) and I didn't get any technical issues, however the forums are full of people with stuttering caused by memory leaks.

I played on SLI 670's with an i5 2500k and had no issues.

The combat here is fantastic, brutal and gory.  The addition of vehicle takedowns makes you feel like a complete badass, and the new ability to turn people into infested grenades is brilliant.

Would recommend to anyone with the caveat that you might have some technical issues.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Bought this game a while ago when it was on sale and just recently got around to playing it. I know a lot of people are saying they can't play it due to technical issues, but I haven't experienced any issue when playing the game. 3 1/2 years since its release and the grphics are still decent even compared to some of the games released nowadays. The controls are easy and flows very nicely. The gameplay is somewhat easy, nothing can really stop you once you get the hang of the abilities, but the game is very fun. The story is there, but the missions are somewhat repetitive, and the upgrades don't seem very meaningful aside from the evolutions. Game is currently on sale again so now is the time to buy it if you like open world, kill everything games with a bit of stealth. Wouldn't recommend at the original £20 price tag but definitely worth £5.

Prototype 2 is to Prototype 1 what Assassins Creed 2 was to Assassins Creed 1. New lead, improved story, inproved mission system, better lvl/upgarde system and a better combat sytem makes this a MUCH improved game.

Out of 10, I easly give this a 9. Buy it.

reviewText: The worst story I've seen in a game... Ever...\nThe gameplay is fun and enjoyable, I think everyone loves to run around butchering people and consuming them but when it comes to the story is when the game falls short. The story feels some what forced. Within the first 10 mins of playing the main protagonist joins Alex mercer who he originally believed to be the bad guy and fights against who he originally believed to be the good guys. There are plenty of plot holes as well, E.G. The priest you meet at the start of the game, who the hell is he? all we are told is that he knows things... HE IS A PRIEST!\nAnyway, te story is too forced, jumping from one scene to the next not really knowing whats happening. It's kind've like the beginning of Farcry 4.

reviewText: It is quite impressive how Radical managed to brake nearly everything that worked just fine in their first [prototype]. Let's start with the main character: Heller is just dumb brute and no amount of his dead loved ones makes him relatable. Mercer's quest for identity was nothig astonishing, but at least his lines were never this cringeworthy. And in no way he deserved to be made into this horrible kind of villain. Movement and fighting mechanics? Never truly shined the way they were intended to thanks to the broken lock on system. Movesets of each weapon are lacking variety and being able to use two at a time doesn't just scratch that itch. And most of the pleasant little details and moves were added only to RADNET edition. The story? Goes all over the place and gets nowhere without a sequel to deliver any catharsis whatsoever.\nVerdict? Play the first one and hope for a reboot. We need a decent [prototype] game on the market and we don't have one yet.

reviewText: This game was not ported well over from the consoles to the PC, and it really shows when you play it. The game itself is immence fun, focusing on openworld exploration and combat, with the main character having crazy genetic based powers. The game itself is all about speed and manuverabilityl, which makes the fact that you can not keep a consistent framerate in this game at all. This makes the game literrally unplayable when too many things are happening on screen. Prototype 2 is never gonna get fixed in any official capacity, and there is no consistent way to make the game run at a decent framerate. This means that for all intents an purposes it is fundamentaly broken and should not be played by anyone who values a smooth experience.

reviewText:
Let me tell you why I started hating this game. You see, instead going fair, the game changes your ♥♥♥♥ing controls during boss battles, you randomly fall through the floor, and some boss battles have non avoidable attacks right after the cutscene, just removing your health for no real reason. Oh, and did I tell you that you can fall through the floor? You can also change gravity and fall upwards, which is kind of entertaining. Or fall through the wall. There are many bugs in the game, and as such, it's not playable. Enemies instantly regenerate all their health by being stuck in an animation. Another fun fact - some of your attacks won't work on bosses. I'm fine with that, but if only the OP attacks work, then the boss battle turn into wathing the same animation forty times, due to the fight difficulty being the incredibly long health bar of your enemies.

The good parts:
+ The game runs smoothly.
+ Free roaming is great.
+ Carnage is fun in the beggining.
+ When the game is not completely broken it's really fun...

The bad parts:
- ...but it is broken all the time.
- Some of your attacks are completely worthless and some are incredibly OP.
- Bosses use unavoidablr attacks to make your life miserable.
- The plot is so stupid, I honestly prefer to watch Batman & Robin to it.
- The main character is the biggest idiot in the gaming universe.
- The plot twists that aren't even changing anything, while being obvious.
- The mentality of most characters points to mental retardation.
- Soundtrack is irremarkable, just generic action game music.
- After some time, everything becomes annoying to the limit, expecially the collectables you need to upgrade.
- Listening to the same lines over and over and over and over...

reviewText: Prototype 2 is an especially good action game where you play the role of sergeant Heller with lethal surpernatural shape-shifting abilities given by Alex Mercer. During the game Heller wants her daughter back and to stop Balckwatch and Mercer from destroying New York. Missions are excellent and contain a lot of fight against Mercer's creatures and Blackwatch elite troopers. You can consume almost everybody to gain health and to obtin memories that help you to understand better the story. In the city you can find collectibles to be found and liars to be cleared for mutators as a reward. Mutators give you superpowers and you can earn XP points by completing missions. As you level up you can open and obtain upgrades that make Heller more deadlier and give you advantage during the gameplay. The game ends with an epic fight against your creator, Alex Mercer. Prototype 2 has the Radnet Access" pack dlc that gives you 5 unique abilities and 50+ challenges to complete. 8/10"

reviewText:
Story is good, combat gameplay is excellent, and the pacing is fine. The only real problem lies within the fact that this is a console port. Nvidia graphics cards have less trouble running the game, but most other cards like ATI have framerate drops to the single digits at random times, regardless of the quality of your other hardware.

One more thing: RAM. Prototype 2 easily eats 3-4GB of RAM constantly. Do not buy unless you have 8GB or more. Occasionally, the game will hog all the RAM and CPU resources and freeze everything, including the task manager. The only known solution is to enter the task manager right after launching the game, and under Processes, Set Affinity to CPU 0 only. Even with this, the game can still become unplayable.

tl;dr - Good game, poorly optimized port.

reviewText:
As far as gameplay goes it's not a terrible game.
You get to run around feeling like a superpowered god, it's fun running around and doing things, and the missions don't drag on.

The bad news is pretty much everything else. If you've played Prototype then you've already done 90% of what Prototype 2 offers.
Except Prototype 2 has a worse story.

I realize in the first game that Alex Mercer isn't really a dynamic or deep character, but the mystery of the situation and the fact that he generally seemed interested in helping people made him appealing.
In Prototype 2 you play Angry Black Man. You can tell this because his name is Heller. He's a part of the military, he has a wife and daughter he loves, and he generally treats everybody like crap.
This is all you ever you will ever know about him.
He get's about 1.5 seconds of character development  during the game that almost made him somewhat human (A later scene with Dana asking her to do something for him, and when he decides not to flat out murder somebody like he normally does).

Mercer is even worse. Since the last game he's done badguy. Why? Uh... don't know?
Since in the last game he's a good guy who's trying to stop the spread of the virus the sudden swithc to deciding that it needs to take over the world is jarring. And they never explain it.

The side missions can be fun, but they're all find this guy and eat him"
recommended: "sneak into this base and eat him"
voteText: or the worst of the lot "Run and collect things that fell out of a helicopter".\nSounds like an okay mix
helpfulPercent: but they get old real quick.\n\nThe main story can be completed in one sitting if you just rush through it
votesHelpful:
and since the story is bizzaro and almost non-existant it's not really worth the effort.

And the ending is really a face palm moment.
**SPOILERS!!!!***









You become some kind of virus god capable of eating all the infected stuff in the entire city.
Because we needed a quick easy way of cleaning up the mess that was New York to make it seem like a real ending.

Like I said
votesTotal: the gameplay is a lot of fun
votesFunny: but personally I'd suggest playing the original."

reviewText:
My thoughts on the game having finished it
I cannot even begin to describe how dissapointed i am in this game, and I say that with great sadness. I have only just finished it so I wish to put my thoughts out there while they are fresh.
if you were looking forward to an interesting improved version over the origional Prototype you will be serverly dissapointed. if you want to have some more fun in the Prototype universe, go play the origional again and save yourself the pain.

Credit where credit is due, Prototype 2 DOES look good, I will give it that. But thats about the ONLY thing it does better then the origional. It just feels as though the developers kinda.. well... dumbed it down for example the progression system in the origional was that you would earn EP (Evolutionary Points) through the main story and through doing side missions and then you could freely choose how you would evolve your character with a few story limitations (which made sence) and could unlock new abilities and combo moves.

In Prototype 2 however the EP that you earn are directly channeled into a liniear level up bar where once it is filled simply gives you a level up point that you can choose to place in either:

Health
Regen
Movement
Mass
Finishers
and Disguise (which in almost completly pointless I might add)

Once the point has been placed it simply gives you a straight up boost to the thing that you choose.... and thats it....how boring. Now before people go off at me YES you can do side missions to aquire mutations" (selectable passives) but again that is quite boring and not worth going after as the game can quite easily be completed without aquireing more then a single passive...

Another problem is that many of the enemies you will encounter are just re-skins. There are some new enemies but most if not all will instantly be recognisable which is a shame.
most of these things I could deal with but what really put the nail in the coffin for me was

*not really a spoiler*

The final boss fight
date: Obviously you fight the protagonist from the first game (Alex Mercer) and I have to say it was one of the worst if not THE worst boss fight I've ever had to force my way through
recommended: because I refused to give up on the game after making it so far
hoursPlayed: but my GOD it was terrible.\n\nI like many of you I'm sure remember building up Alex to be the ultimate badass killing machine. Yet once you reach him
voteText: to destroy your maker.... it's just pathedic. The fight is a spam fest of dodging and back stabbing with scripted movements
helpfulPercent: camera angles and area restricting nonsence.\n\nFirst off. The spam. my GOD the spam. Yourself and Alex literally jump around each other constantly because many of Alexes attacks are unblockable and auto hit unless you are spamming the hell out of dodge. Then once you land behind him you back stab him a few times
votesHelpful: then rinse and repeat.\n\nThe camera angles kind of lead into the area restriction problem. you confront alex on top of a building and after having the whole game free roam
votesTotal: you are now restricted to this one roof top for the duration of this fight and in doing so the camera has to use funky angles just to try and keep up with all the stuff flying around the screen causing many
votesFunny:
MANY problems and it is just stupid. Yes the origional did the same with its boss fight but at least it had a semi decent reason of being on an aircraft carrier and at the very LEAST that boss had minimal scripting and the fight was still "free roam"

In all honesty it would have been better if they had just made Alex like the (minor spoiler) Evolved where they fought you around the city in free roam. It would have made the fight so much better.

All in all I am dissapointed which makes me very depressed as I absolutly loved the first game and played the hell out of it

reviewText:
At first, this game looked to be a slightly upgrading version of the first Prototype: similar powers, better upgrade system, same silly story, slightly better gameplay.  Then out of left field comes the crippling framerate issues.  Apparently if you have an AMD graphics card, this game's framerate turns into a Powerpoint presentation as soon as one of the following things happens:

1) It rains. (This happens fairly frequently.)
2) A helicopter shows up. (Ditto.)
3) The game just wants to ♥♥♥♥ with you. (I SENSE A PATTERN HERE.)

Keep in mind that this is with the graphics set to the lowest possible settings.  Even then the framerate issues persisted, and I eventually just gave up.  I've jumped through MANY hoops to play good games (I spent nearly 2 days getting both Fallout 3 and Myst to work on my PC) but this game appears to run like ♥♥♥♥ for no reason whatsoever - I've tried multiple fixes on the internet but nothing has worked.

I paid 15 dollars for this and regret it, because I didn't even get to play the whole damn game.  A huge disappointment considering that I enjoyed the previous game in the franchise.
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The game is more like a alternate verison of Prototype 1. They improved some gameplay aspects to give more usability, but the story didn't draw me in at all, mainly do to a crap main character and turning Alex into a maniac without explaining why. Heller was crude, abrasive, and had a rather dull oneliner for every situation. Using the zombie skin that turned most of his dialogue into hisses and growls made the game significantly better (and not just for the absurdity value).
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game has a serious unadressed bug, that means after about 5 to 10 minutes the game goes from 24fps (its internal frame rate cap) to between 8 and 10 and becomes unplayable. Alt+Tab forces the game to do some form of cleanup, and the game will return to 24fps for a bit. If you don't mind having to deal with huge frame rate drops, and Alt-Tabbing constantly to fix the game, then maybe this game is for you. Consider though, that this isn't even the worst of the bugs people are reporting, and the studio that made the game has been closed.\n\nI paid £5 and that was £5 too much.

reviewText:
I usually do not write a bad review if I cannot play the game (afterall the game could be really good), however because many people had the same problems:

I tried for hours to actually start the game, but it always stopped working. And when I finally managed that, it keeps hanging or crashing after a few minutes in game.

So if you try your luck, make sure you do not try for to long so you can refund it if necessary.

reviewText:
You should have played Prototype 1 first to understand most of the story.

The game is good, NY is big and buildings good detailed. You can drive with tanks and fly with helicopters but not with normal cars = bad :( .

You can use all weapons from soldiers and you can grab weapons from helis and more but your best weapon is you and the virus in you.

Game has many side missions and bonus events, i guess cause of a bit too short story. The final fight was good but nothing special, end sequence also bit too short. All in one its a cool game cause of your cool arms and the great city which is fully open.

Sometimes i had some mysterious game crash without any known reason. or it starts to lag a bit and then crash but it was not that much for getting angry. :)

7/10

reviewText: I originally played this on a console and thought it was reasonably good, so when it popped up in the steam sale for next to nothing, nostalgia took over and i bought it. However, I wish i hadn't now.\n\nWhile the game is a ok'ish game, the performance issues make it unplayable and I had to uninstall. I have a good workstation PC with an i7, SSD, 32gb of ram etc... and even on all the lowest settings this games frame rate drops to unplayable levels. All the other 100+ games I have on steam don't have this issue on medium or high settings, so it must either be that the game is buggy or it's not liking a particular piece of hardware or software i have. Either way, I can't recommend in it's current state and like a few other games, I wish i could get a refund, but i know that will probably never happen on steam.

reviewText: Having already played Prototype, mixed feelings. Upgrade system is improved, but starting out with so many powers as opposed to gaining them organically makes being a superhero less special. Too easy to run/fly away from alerts. Conversely, couldn't finish the game because of a mandatory stealth mission. Didn't want to continue after losing to a giant tentacle or something which I could have killed if I wasn't responsible for babysitting the military while restricted to using guns that took several attempts to pick up and fire in the right direction. Only fun if you're content to ignore the story, screw around and throw civilians and military personnel across buildings, and you have Garry's Mod for that. Not enough bang for twice as much buck.

reviewText:
Welcome to New York Zero.

The sequel to Radical Entertainment’s best-selling open-world action game of 2009, Prototype® 2 takes the unsurpassed carnage of the original Prototype and continues the experience of becoming the ultimate shape-shifting weapon. You are Sgt James Heller, husband to a deceased wife and child and a soldier left simply to die.

As the game’s all-new infected protagonist, players will experience Sgt James Heller cutting a bloody swathe through the wastelands of post-viral New York Zero. Equipped with unparalleled new shapeshifting powers,players will gradually build a vast genetic arsenal of deadly new biological weapons and abilities as they hunt, kill and consume their way toward the ultimate goal – to kill…Alex…Mercer!

Are you ready to murder your maker?

It'll try to keep my review short this time.
Combat i fun and seems varied but gets repetetive and unchallenging later on.
The world is smaller and less interesting than previously.
The rpg aspect is limited at best, and annoyingly it's impossible to fully develop your chracter in one playthrough.
The main chracter is a huge ♥♥♥&hole. Really, really a hatefull jerk. The daughter and family parts don't match the character you play and seem like they were added last minute to make him more likable, they do not. This i consider a cheap move which ruins any story. This is best shown in Mercer, who is out of nowhere a psychopath. I was most angered by that, as i liked him in P1. So yeah good going, P2 story team.

All in all, Prototype is a good for a bit of combat, but not much else. I don't recommend it. Even if it is on sale, there are better games for you to play.

reviewText:
Only buy this game if it is on sale for $5 or less and you have an Nvidia graphics card. If you look at the steam forums many people with AMD cards can't even start this game.
I was able to run this game on max settings, getting consistent 55-63 fps, only had a few drops below 50 but never below 40.

Good
- Fun action (sometimes ruined by the camera and controls)
- Fun gore

Bad
- Storyline, very predictable (2/3 through the story i had to start skipping the cut scenes due to the stupidity of all characters)
- MC is very 1 dimensional, and can't jump, run, or do anything besides walking at normal (human) pace while on a cell phone -_-

Horrible
- Camera, I died many many times due to the camera focusing on a wall instead of infected I was fighting. The camera is so bad it actually ruined the last half of the game as I realized it was my main enemy.
- Controls, in part due to the worthless camera and part trying to sneak up on a enemy who happened to be next to something you could pick up, you have a %50 chance to grab the enemy or grab the object breaking your sneak and alerting everyone.

reviewText:
You really should buy this game! It comes packed with challenges that are harder than Prototype 1. My favorite one is trying to get to the loading screen without a crash of some sort. But don't get me wrong, these challenges are widespread! If you manage to get to the loading screen, there is a 95% chance of the game crashing before you get to the main menu. I've only seen the main menu once! This game brings the difficulty to a whole new level.

Buy this game if you want to experience any of these things:
-Frustration
-Empty wallet
-Soul sold to Activision
-Not playing the game
-False hope
-Trying hopelessly to revive the game long enough to see a title screen
-Further frustration

I also hear that the game part of the game is very mediocre, but I have yet to reach that part.
10/10

reviewText: This is a great game for letting off steam, something to just load up to run around blowing things apart. It has a decent storyline, and some of the challenges are fun..but the best part is just rampaging around. If you are squeamish at all to the smallest amount of blood or death, then turn around and uninstall..this game is not for you. Otherwise I highly recommend this game, but I recommend using a controller to play it as the mouse & keyboard option feels very sloppy. Perhaps it's because I played this for like 50 hours on ps3 and I'm just used to the controller..but that's my opinion.\n\nGraphics are average, with controller movement is easy to get used to and pretty well-done.  This is easily one of the bloodiest & most violent games i've ever played, so be warned. Story is good enough, but fairly predictable and unoriginal. Voice acting is nice, they did good in that aspect (at least for the main characters). Completely open world, minus going into buildings or swimming..or leaving the island (they will just shoot you down with rockets). Several very fun powers, pretty much all melee but powerful..and you can basically fly. You can hijack vehicles including helicopters & powerful tanks.. and use guns that the enemy drops, the only useful one being the rocket launcher, however.  The upgrades you get improve you a huge amount over time and are very satisfying.  I don't want to give away any spoilers, but some of the big boss fights are quite memorible.

Yes, BUT...

... be warned. This game is more glitchy than Alex Mercer's genetic code. I had it crash on me three times since I installed it... -yesterday-.

Otherwise the gameplay is solid, the graphics are nice, the combat is well thought out, and I love how the cutscenes are done all artsy black and white Sin City style.

One small niggle I do have though is this: Why the hell did Activision change how the stealth devour works? There was nothing wrong with holding down RB and then pressing Y. voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Loved this game. Yes it has a memory leak for pc but dont let that discourage you! The game changes up some things from the first game that didnt work well. One was the minigames; screw those and just have them integrated into the missions. Make enemies easier to consume when they're at low health. Have new game changing abilities, all of which you will use and be encouraged to use. A little more help to get you through the game easier. It might seem like a little much at first but believe me as someone who is a slow learner, it's worthwhile. I loved the perk system and level up system. Unfortunately there isnt a counter for body count anymore or any reason to randomly kill military but you get everything with the second playthrough as long as you do some searching around the city. One suggestion that I wish I knew going into the game: THE MAP HELPS YOU FIND BLACK BOXES, DENS, AND FIELD TEAMS! The general area is pinged on the map if you have something undiscovered. Use this info to your advantage! It can be found under collectibles in the map tabs.

My favorite ability is the Bio-Bomb! I literally spent 2 hours alone playing around with it. There is also a RadNet change to it that allows you to kick those you bio-bomb square in the ♥♥♥ toward your target! It's fantastic. It allows me to stealth missions easier while removing detectors to move around easier. I used it a lot to stealth kill tanks and helicopters ahead of time for missions. Totally the most useful skill out of combat and can be used for fun in combat as well.

Happy hunting!

reviewText: Overall, Prototype 2 is a more polished but more streamlined version of the first Prototype. If the Prototypes were computers, Prototype would be a Windows- more features, but more complicated and less polished- while Prototype 2 would be a Mac- slightly less features and slightly less depth, but much more fun to use and play, although it holds your hands a bit too much sometimes.\n\nCompared to the original Prototype, Prototype 2 improves upon the areas in which the first Prototype failed. Graphics are very pretty to look at, especially at night. Gameplay is smoother and less chaotic. And each power has a more distinct style and strength to it, although you may argue that this is worse than Prototype's combo-based combat. I never really got into it, so I prefer Prototype 2's more linear combat more. Also, dodging is easier now, and you can actually combine abilities to create new attacks in the sequel. Its story, although not very good, is more organized than Prototype's, and I felt it had an overall structure to it, rather than Prototype's I hate everyone let's go kill them". Stealth is also better in Prototype 2
date: and stealth consumes are much easier to perform with the all-new "hunt" feature.\n\nHowever
recommended: Prototype 2 also got rid of statistics and the nice "military expenditure" screen that popped up at the end of every fight
voteText: as I always wanted to know how much damage I was causing the military and Blackwatch (especially with those new vehicle finishers- those are fun!). Prototype 2 uses a very linear and cliche leveling-up system
helpfulPercent: and I prefered the original's more open upgrade system
votesHelpful: where you could allocate points in very specific areas that you wanted to improve upon
votesTotal: rather than just a more general area.\n\nWhat I missed the most
votesFunny: however
commentsCount: was Prototype's progression. As the story progressed
column16: you saw NYC turn into a more military-run place
column17: with infection slowly destroying the city throughout. Police are replaced by squads of soldiers
column18: and overall there is a real sense of progression as you play through the game. You feel like you are really living in a viral outbreak. Prototype 2 had none of that. It had the zones instead
column19: which overall fall flat (the Green and Yellow zones are basically stepping-stones for you to progress through to the Red zone). They do have a very distinct quality between each
column20: but they don't give the sense of progression and decay that the original Prototype had.\n\nSo- should you buy this game? Yes. And if you haven't played Prototype 1- buy and play it. Both have their own little merits that are worth experiencing
column21: and I would happily recommend them both."

reviewText:
A good hacking slashing brawl with ideas.... but if you are using a AMD card, I recommend you to not buy this game or you will crash every 15 minutes or so

Pros:
A nice health system where you regen health by consuming people and taking there disguise.
Nice movement system but at first it abit weird, i recommend upgrading it first.
You gain new powers at certain missions which open up the combat: There are human types that die quickly and can be consumed then there the 1v1 types that require your powers to stun then or other things.
The random upgrade system works well; You either sneak up on them and consume them, grab them and consume them, if they are a 1v1 enemy beat them up and then consume then but your enemies like killing them.
The powers are nice.

Cons:
I recommend doing story missions to gain all of the powers
You can pick up guns but the targeting system is hard to use, and if you want to use your powers you drop your guns, you cant hold any guns.
The tanks and helicopter suck since you are a mortal god.
When 3 or more 1v1 enemies come out, it is annoying as they need you to focus on them but they rush you
At the beginning, your health dont regen unless you eat it
The side missions are cool but you need to often hunt a target to do the mission, The audio logs are hard to find sometimes.
Heller isnt the great protaginst and is generic
The missions you got to stay in disguise and use guns against 1v1 enemies get annoying.
Amd video cards cause the game to crash or freeze up like there is no tomorrow

I recommend this game but make sure you dont have a AMD, It a pretty good sandbox game

reviewText:
I'll make this short and to the point:

Achievements

This is one of the few games that works gathering achievements into story progression thus making it nearly impossible to miss as you progress.  Other than that, it has an even amount of progression and skill based achievements that will keep you engaged.

Story

It plays like a mini-scifi/horror tv series that is a bit on the raw side with good acting and cut sequences.

Combat

It is extremely fluid and flexible and will appeal to both digital samurai and button mashers. However, this is NOT the type of game you play with a keyboard and mouse...

Graphics

They're not the best nor are they the worse - it's a happy medium considering it's a sandbox environment. Load times are near instant on medium systems and there is virtually no FPS choke points that I've encountered despite the hundreds upon hundreds of zombies roaming the city...

Overall, this is one of those weekend warrior games that will keep you entertained and decently challenged for a good 30 hours...That’s if you’re going for 100% completion.

However, my only complaint is that you can't reach 100% completion without starting a new game on insane mode and racing through the storyline. I bought the DLC thinking that I could finish things up but alas, the EP gains are null.

So in other words, buy the dlc for the mini games (which are challenging and fun), but start a 2nd playthrough on insane mode (which inherits everything you've completed in past game modes and only takes a couple of hours) for the extra EP if you want to complete it.

reviewText:
Prototpe 2 feels like a much better version of prototype.
Some examples: what i didn't like in prototype was that you have an open world but nothing is really happening in this world besides the military and the infected. The civilians were just wandering around pointlessly. In prototype 2 the civilians talk to each other about the infection and about blackwatch killing civilians which drags you as the player way deeper in this scenario.
Another thing i didn' like in prototype was that the combat wasn't really dynamic you chose one power at the start and if you wanted to change it you needed to access the menu. In prototype 2 you can select 2 powers on your 2 mouse keys. For example you can make left click a claw attack and right click a tendril attack which improves the combat system alot because you can now be more creative in killing enemies.

In prototype 2 the NY is divided in 3 different zones depending on the level of infection in this zone. There is the green, yellow and red zone. All these zones feel unique because of the way the artists designed them. For example in the yellow zone you got demonstrations against blackwatch and civilians in cages while in the red zone you find infected wandering around everywhere a lot of destroyed buildings.

In prototype 2 the evolution of the protagonist isn't done with spending ep for new moves anymore. It's more like in a RPG you get ep and after you have enough you get a level up which grants you a point that you can spend in different categories.
There are also other mutations" that you get after completing certain events in a package or finishing //BLACKNET-Missions.
Your powers and skills to work with weapons or vehicles get upgraded by consuming marked targets with an "strong-arm-symbol" over their head.

To sum it all up prototype 2 is a different appraoch to the prototype franchise then prototype. If you liked prototype 1 you should definately play prototype 2."

reviewText:
This game is way more fun than it has any right to be. The plot and characterization is reminescent of recent Michael Bay movies. It's just a hodge podge of nonsenical reasons for you to blow things up, a borderline racist depiction of a black main character, and a peppering super sexualized supporting characters. The dialogue oozes with the maturity of teenage focus group testing and is the kind of thing I may have thought was amazing when I was in middle school. Everything about Prototype 2's story is a vast step backward from Prototype.

Despite all of that, I still had a blast, because the mechanics of the game feel good. They make you feel powerful. Thankfully, there is no pretense of heroism throughout most of Prototype 2, so  you never feel guilty about using and abusing every bipedal meat buffet in your vicinity. It wants you to wreck everything around you, and makes it feel good to do so.

It's better than the original Prototype because many design concessions have been made for the sake of playability. Rockets are now telegraphed by a laser and a beeping sound you will hear long after you stop playing the game. Upgrades are handled differently and the majority of them are awards for completing side objectives that are surprisingly fun to complete. This means that the collectible component in most free roaming games is actually meaningful in this game.

All in all, a fantastic experience.

reviewText:
Do not pay $39.99 for this. It's a good game. Its fun. But with how crappy it runs on my capable computer and how old the game is I will have to say that if I paid $39.99 for this game I would feel ripped off.

This is a great sandbox game. Controls are amazing once you get used to them. Leveling up will grant you godly abilities to run, leap and glide across the city, slaughtering countless people who get in your way.

I havent completed the game yet, but I do not feel like it will be too too extensive. Just a fun, turn it on and screw around game. I get pulled into the side missions and trying to get a gold rating. Very fun stuff to fine tune your skills. Also you get exp and new mutations from completion. Making it very much worth it to stay on top of the side missions.

If you see this game for $9.99 or less, I would strongly suggest buying it. Unless your computer sux.

*Edit* Just found out that it was my AMD video card that is causing all the problems. I also found a thread with a fix for the memmory leak problem. Search it up in the community hub. Value of game just went up.

reviewText:
Bloody Fun

If you want to be a super-powered behemoth with no regard for human life, tearing through a devastated NYC with an assortment of violent super-powers, then look no further. If you played the first one you'll know what to expect, just bigger, and more.

I found this game fun, neither too challenging nor too easy. It didn't make me think, it didn't ask me to make choices, it just gave me things to smash in hilarious and exciting ways. The characters and plot are laughably bad, and I actually really enjoyed them in a B-movie kind of way. About half way through I did start skipping through every cinematic, but this in no way affected my understanding or enjoyment of the game.

A great game to play after a hard day if you want to just turn off and laugh (hopefully with a friend, the co-op was surprisingly fun!)

reviewText:
Worthy sequel to the 1st game. Fixes the few annoying bits of the 1st game (the repetitive base infiltration segments that ended up all feeling the same) and adds even more enjoyable & destructive modes. The story is nearly as good as in the original due to fact while it doesn't have the same crazy twist, you do get to turn the tables on the previous anti-hero and main character of the previous game as Alex Mercer is now the main villain and you end up having a kick-♥♥♥ epic battle against him.
I also have to say that I'm a bit biased as there are very few games where the main character is black and well-done, and being a black man I'm always looking for more cultural diversity in my games. So it helps that while being a one dimensional-character James Heller is pretty decent as far as characters go. It would have been nice though to have him interact more with his daughter as at times it doesn't feel like she's a big part of his life or the main reason why he's fighting and he can come off as just another really angry black man.
The gameplay is akin to that in the first game as you can run up buildings, toss cars, glide across rooftops and from on end of the city to the other as you become more powerful and run at such speeds through the streets of NYC that the ground cracks under your feet and you feel that sense of mass and speed as you collide with NPCs and other elements in the environment and send them flying! Being a superhero (cause face it, that's basically what you are) rarely ever felt this good :D
The combat is also a lot of fun as your various virus-related abilities make you feel increasingly powerful and badass and you can carve (literally lol!) a path of utter destruction through your enemies and the city of NY. It's a joy to experiment with your increasing array of lethal abilities and learning what works best against which enemy and being able to weaponize grenade launchers and other weaponry that you literally rip from vehicles is a blast xD

8.75/10

reviewText: Wow I loved this game. I really enjoyed the first one also. I think this is one definitely the better one. The combat is improved 100% by the new shield ability. reviewText: Prototype 2 does feel like an improved sequel, graphics are sharper, nice color effects though it still feels unoptimized like its predecessor. The story gets better, more insanity and badass. Combat system feels alot closer to something like the batman games which I thought was a better combat system compared to P1. Upgrades are received via challenges and missions instead of XP like P1. I got P1 & P2 + DLC from amazon for like $7.50 a few months ago, great deal for great games.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: As chaotic as its predecessor but more focused and refined this time arround. Sadly, the same can't be said about the actual port itself however, as visuals can be described as unimpressive at best and ,even worse, the framerate is inconsistent and inexcusably low. The game took me 15hrs on hard with all side objectives done. There is a freeroam mode after the ending and also an NG+ & a higher difficulty unlock. Heller takes time to reach his lvl cap + there are random permanent power up boosts that you may miss by accident (the power up target dies, etc), so a 2nd playthrough is pretty much guaranteed if you want to 100% the game. There isn't much mission variety but thankfully playing as a walking apocalypse never gets old. The story isn't particularly great but it's enough to make you want to progress further. All in all it's worth a look.
